awd_titl_txt: Electrowetting-assisted Dropwise Condensation on Hybrid Superhydrophobic-Hydrophilic Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Water consumed by thermal power generation stations accounts for 40% of total US freshwater withdrawal. This is non-sustainable; hence, electric utilities need more water-efficient methods for cooling. Heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) systems also suffer from inefficient cooling technologies, resulting in excessive energy demands. In these applications, waste heat is removed when water vapor condenses on a metal surface forming a continuous liquid film.  This layer of water conducts heat poorly, compared to the metal, and so decreases system efficiency.  However, if the metal surface is modified to repel water, the vapor will condense in the form of droplets that roll-off the surface before forming a continuous liquid film. After rolling off, the metal surface is re-exposed. This results in enhanced performance that reduces cooling water consumption; increases electrical efficiency; and lessens the environmental impact of the process.  These benefits result in smaller condensers and reduced capital and operational expenditures.

In this NSF project, we fabricate novel condenser surfaces that increase energy efficiency in thermal power generation and HVAC by promoting dropwise condensation through a combination of superhydrophobicity and electro-wetting. The influence of phenomena like electrowettability, gas diffusion, thermal transport and Marangoni convection on the stability of the Cassie state are studied using a combination of modeling and experiments. This requires capturing the effects of deforming menisci and, once the liquid phase reaches the advancing contact angle, moving triple contact lines. EW-induced pumping on textured superhydrophobic surfaces is studied. Novel pumping configurations are analyzed, wherein AC electric fields induce a body force and a torque on the droplet to initiate its ?rolling? on superhydrophobic surfaces. Materials/manufacturing issues associated with the development of durable, scalable, polymer coatings for dropwise condensation are also investigated and will be shared through outreach to local high school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Condensation heat transfer, i.e., transition from vapor to liquid, of, e.g., water is critical in many applications such as the generation of electrical power and air-conditioning. It also holds promise in the cooling of computers and data centers as well as the self-cleaning of solar photovoltaic panels. There are two primary modes of condensation; filmwise condensation, where a film of liquid runs down a surface, and dropwise condensation, where droplets form on a surface and roll off. Dropwise condensation is much more efficient than filmwise condensation, i.e., it leads to better rates of heat transfer and can thus improve the performance of the aforementioned power plants and air conditioners and may in the future enable faster computers via improved heat transfer and more efficient solar panel arrays by reducing soiling losses. However, stable dropwise condensation has been very difficult to achieve and the result is that is not exploited in commercially-available equipment.

 The work done on this project helped advanced the state-of-the-art in, ultimately, enabling stable dropwise condensation that can be exploited commercially. Specific accomplishments were as follows. 1) We improved our understanding of the chemical bonds necessary to attach polymers conducive to dropwise condensation to surfaces. 2) We advanced our understanding of how self-cleaning surfaces relying on mobile droplets of water may be used to enhance the performance of solar panels. 3) We showed that electrowetting, i.e., the use of electric fields to alter the behavior of water droplets, can be used to enhance dropwise condensation by providing control of how droplets are formed and leave a surface. 4) We gained an understanding of how biomimetic surfaces that behave like the Lotus leaf may be designed to avoid them failing to maintain their self-cleaning/superhydrophobic effect. The funding also trained undergraduate and graduate students at 3 universities, the City University of New York, the University of Texas at Austin and Tufts University in the broad field of heat transfer, which is critical to the generation of power and air conditioning, amongst many other applications.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2022
Modified by: Alan Lyons

Images (1 of )
  • Water condensed on a surface (eg. windshield) can be swept away using an electrical technique, as per a comparison of (a) and (b). Water removal action is dependent on the frequency of the electrical waveform used.
    Bahadur group@UTPermission
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Alan Lyons
    Removing water from a surface via electrical means (analogous to an electrical windshield wiper)
  • Water droplets on a water repelling surface can be electrically aggregated to promote faster removal. Data from imaging visualization can be used to train machine learning algorithms to predict extent of coalescence.
    Bahadur group@UTmission
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Alan Lyons
    Machine learning-based predictive modeling of electrocoalescence of water droplets
  • On hydrophobic surfaces, soiling levels were significantly lower than on hydrophilic bare glass surfaces. Increasing soilant hygroscopicity increased soiling levels only on hydrophilic bare glass surfaces.
    Lyons group at CUNY
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Alan Lyons
    Effect of surface hydrophobicity and soilant chemistry on soiling levels
  • Arrays of hydrophilic bare glass channels on a hydrophobic coating accelerate nucleation and growth of condensate leading to more efficient cleaning and water collection. Increasing hygroscopicity of soilants increases water collection yields, especially on hydrophobic glass surfaces.
    Lyons group at CUNY
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Alan Lyons
    Effect of surface patterning, wetting and soilant hygroscopicity on water collection during condensation
  • XPS was used to characterize the compositional variation of FEP laminated to glass as a function of depth. Sodium diffusion from the glass reacts with fluorine released by FEP to form NaF at the interface. This water-soluble salt explains the observed adhesion loss under accelerated temperature
    Lyons group at CUNY
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Alan Lyons
    XPS depth profile of fluorinated ethylene propylene (FEP) laminated to low-iron soda lime PV cover glass.
